questions.question_text: Which two actions guarantee that time is synchronized properly on all nodes in a cluster after installing Oracle Grid Infrastructure 19c? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
If you have NTP daemons on your server but you cannot configure them to synchronize time with a time server, and you want to use Cluster Time Synchronization Service to provide synchronization service in the cluster, then deactivate and deinstall the NTP. When the installer finds that the NTP protocol is not active, the Cluster Time Synchronization Service is installed in active mode and synchronizes the time across the nodes.

If NTP is found configured, then the Cluster Time Synchronization Service is started in observer mode, and no active time synchronization is performed by Oracle Clusterware within the cluster.
---
• Active Mode: CTSSD acts as the primary time synchronization service for the cluster.
• Observer Mode: CTSSD monitors the system time but relies on the NTP service for synchronization. This happens when a properly configured and reliable NTP service is detected.
D: if NTP==> CTSSD is observer E: If no NTP: CTSSD is active

Selected Answer: DE
DE correct

Selected Answer: DE
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/cwlin/setting-network-time-protocol-for-cluster-time-synchronization.html#GUID-D2CDFAC3-4CE2-4E56-B34F-81D0FD20CEFA

If you have NTP daemons on your server but you cannot configure them to synchronize time with a time server, and you want to use Cluster Time Synchronization Service to provide synchronization service in the cluster, then deactivate and deinstall the NTP. 
When the installer finds that the NTP protocol is not active, the Cluster Time Synchronization Service is installed in active mode and synchronizes the time across the nodes. If NTP is found configured, then the Cluster Time Synchronization Service is started in observer mode, and no active time synchronization is performed by Oracle Clusterware within the cluster.

choices.A: If network time protocol (NTP) time servers are unreachable on any cluster node, then Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will start automatically in active mode when the clusterware is started.
choices.E: Deactivate network time protocol (NTP) on all cluster nodes; Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will then start automatically in active mode when the clusterware is started.
choices.B: Configure network time protocol (NTP) on all cluster nodes, and then start the Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) in active mode on all cluster nodes.
choices.C: If network time protocol (NTP) is not configured properly on all cluster nodes, then Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will start automatically in active mode when the clusterware is started.
choices.D: Configure network time protocol (NTP) on all cluster nodes; Oracle Cluster Time Synchronization Service (CTSSD) will then start automatically in observer mode when the clusterware is started.

discussion.content:
A: true
B: false, it will delete the -current node by itself.
C: false, compared to D, host03 will be closed only after the ASM client on currentnode leaves.
D: true
E: false, compared to A
F: true, the ASM instance setting is 2, it is possible that host02 does not have config in ASM.
 ADF
It just cannot be F - simply because it's opossite to literally every other answer, and you need 3.

Selected Answer: BDF
I have found from documentation F is correct.

You can also use SRVCTL to determine whether Oracle Flex ASM is enabled. If enabled, then srvctl config asm displays the number of Oracle ASM instances that has been specified for use with the Oracle Flex ASM configuration.

Selected Answer: BDF
i think BDF correct

comments.content:
Can't be F. Because in B and D ASM instance is running on HOST 2. So how come it's not configured in F.
I think BDE.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
B. Correct because the relocation process involves starting the ASM instance on the target node (HOST02) and not shutting down the ASM instance on the current node (HOST03) until all clients have disconnected.
C. Correct because once the ASM instance is started on HOST02 and all clients have disconnected from HOST03, the ASM instance on HOST03 is shut down.
D. Correct because after the relocation, database instances can reconnect to the ASM instance now running on HOST02.
E. Incorrect because the ASM instance is being relocated to HOST02, not HOST01. Thus, database instances should reconnect to HOST02, not HOST01.

I vote BDF.
Why F?
You can also use SRVCTL to determine whether Oracle Flex ASM is enabled. If enabled, then srvctl config asm displays the number of Oracle ASM instances that has been specified for use with the Oracle Flex ASM configuration. For example:


Copy
$ srvctl config asm
ASM instance count: 3

Selected Answer: BDE
Answer: BDE

questions.question_text:
Examine the output of the asmcmd and srvctl commands:
//IMG//

Then you execute this command:
$ srvctl relocate asm -currentnode host03 -targetnode host02
Which three statements are true regarding the execution of this command based on the output shown? (Choose three.)

choices.E: It succeeds and 19c database instances connected to the ASM instance on HOST03 can be reconnected to the ASM instance on HOST01.
choices.D: It succeeds and 19c database instances connected to the ASM instance on HOST03 can be reconnected to the ASM instance on HOST02.
choices.A: It fails because the ASM instance has not been shut down first on HOST03.
choices.C: It succeeds and starts an ASM instance on HOST02 and shuts down the ASM instance on HOST03.
choices.B: It succeeds and starts an ASM instance on HOST02 but the ASM instance on HOST03 is not shut down until all connected clients disconnect.
choices.F: It fails because an ASM instance is not configured to run on HOST02.

choices.D: AR is available only on the CDB1 instance on HOST01.
choices.B: AR runs as a singleton service in the server pool prod_pool and the AR service is available in each of the CDB1 instances.
choices.A: AR can fail over to any one of the available CDB1 instances.
choices.C: AR can fail over to any other available CDB1 instance in prod_pool.
choices.E: AR is available on any one available CDB1 instance in prod_pool at any one time.

questions.question_text:
You administer a six-instance, policy-managed, multitenant RAC database CDB1 with three PDBs: PDB_1,PDB_2, and PDB_3.
Server pool prod_pool has a cardinality of three and all six hosts of the cluster are up.
Examine these commands executed on HOST01:
//IMG//

Which two statements are true regarding the AR service? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
C. AR can fail over to any other available CDB1 instance in prod_pool.
 
E. AR is available on any one available CDB1 instance in prod_pool at any one time.

singleton ==> So C. AR can fail over to any other available CDB1 instance in prod_pool.
 
E. AR is available on any one available CDB1 instance in prod_pool at any one time.

Selected Answer: CD
C: Server pool isolate members of cluster, so service can failover only on member of server pool.
D: AR is a new service and srvctl start executed on host1 starts service on that host. Service is running only on host1 because of cardinality.
CE ; E...one (any) instance from the pool in one time. A...all the instances are not in the prod_pool ( just 3 of them)

Selected Answer: AC
A - true - AR can fail over to any instance (all the instances are in prod_pool)
B - false - AR is singleton service - it can run only on one instance
C - true (all the CDB1 instances run in the prod_pool)
D - false - we do not know if cdb1 instance is running on host01 now
E - false - AR is singleton service - it can run only on one instance at the time

Selected Answer: ACF
Policy is initially inactive and when you active the policy, the policy apply rules on server pool

Selected Answer: ABC
A. Correct - When a policy is activated, resources can be automatically stopped to comply with the policy definition.
B. Correct - An administrator-defined policy may be activated using the srvctl utility.
C. Correct - When a policy is first created, it is initially inactive

comments.content: You have choosen four. ABC is correct

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ABF
A. Correct - When a policy is activated, resources can be automatically stopped to comply with the policy definition.
B. Correct - An administrator-defined policy may be activated using the srvctl utility.
C. Correct - When a policy is first created, it is initially inactive.
D. Incorrect - When a policy is first created, it is initially inactive, not active.
E. Incorrect - When a policy is activated, resources can be automatically started to comply with the policy definition.
F. Correct and is more correct than C - When a policy is activated, nodes may be reassigned to server pools based on the policy definition.

Selected Answer: ACF
B is wrong - srvctl is for database server pools not policies.

choices.C: When a policy is first created, it is initially inactive.
choices.A: When a policy is activated, resources can be automatically stopped to comply with the policy definition.
choices.B: An administrator-defined policy may be activated using the srvctl utility.
choices.E: When a policy is activated, resources cannot be automatically started to comply with the policy definition.
choices.D: When a policy is first created, it is initially active.
choices.F: When a policy is activated, nodes may be reassigned to server pools based on the policy definition.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true concerning activation of a user-defined policy in Oracle 19c Clusterware? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A. Correct - crsctl set trace res "resource_name=debugging_level": Used to set resource debugging level.
B. Correct - crsctl set log res "resource_name=debugging_level": Used to set logging level for resources.
C. Incorrect - _USR_ORA_DEBUG=1 and restart resource: Not used for Clusterware resource debugging.
D. Incorrect - cluvfy comp command: Used for component verification, not resource debugging.

questions.question_text: Which two methods exist for enabling the collection of additional resource debugging information for specific resources controlled by Oracle 19c Clusterware? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Use the crsctl set trace res "resource_name=debugging_level" command.
choices.B: Use the crsctl set log res "resource_name=debugging_level2" command.
choices.D: Use the cluvfy comp command for the specific resource within a component.
choices.C: Set the environment variable _USR_ORA_DEBUG=1 and then stop and restart the resource that requires resource debugging data to be collected.
